Question: What is text summarization?

Question: What are the Data Transmission Modes in a network?

Question: What is a Subnet mask?

Question: What are various Message switching techniques?
Model Answer: message switching is a method of transmitting data between devices or systems by dividing the message into small units called packets which are then transmitted separately and reassembled at the destination there are three main message switching techniques store-and-forward in this technique the entire message is first received and stored at each intermediate node in the network before being forwarded to the next node in the path to the destination each node verifies the integrity of the message and waits for a confirmation from the next node before forwarding it this technique is reliable but slow as it requires the entire message to be received before forwarding it cut-through in this technique the message is forwarded as soon as the first packet is received by the intermediate node without waiting for the entire message to be received this technique is faster than store-and-forward as it eliminates the need to store and verify the entire message before forwarding it however it is less reliable as errors in the message may not be detected until the entire message is received source routing in this technique the source device specifies the path that the message should take to reach the destination including the intermediate nodes to be used each intermediate node reads the path information and forwards the message to the next node specified in the path this technique provides more control over the routing of messages but requires more processing power at the source device to determine the optimal path

Question: Describe Validation-based locking protocols?
Model Answer: validation-based locking protocols are a type of distributed locking protocol that are used to maintain consistency across distributed databases they work by having the client or server validate the lock before it is granted this validation process ensures that only one process has access to a given resource at any given time preventing race conditions and other issues that can arise in a distributed system validation-based locking protocols typically require some form of communication between the client and server such as a two-phase commit protocol to ensure that the lock is valid before granting it
User Answer: validation-based locking protocols are a type of database locking protocol that uses validation checks to ensure data consistency these protocols use a combination of locks and validation checks to ensure that the data being accessed is up-to-date and consistent with other transactions validation-based locking protocols are typically used in distributed databases where more than one user may be accessing the same data at any given time the main purpose of these protocols is to prevent concurrent access to the same data by multiple users thus avoiding conflicts and ensuring data integrity validation-based locking protocols generally involve two steps first an exclusive lock is placed on the data item before it can be accessed then a validation check is performed on the item before it can be updated or modified this ensures that no other transaction has modified the item since it was locked thus preserving its integrity

Question: Describe Timestamp based locking protocols?
Model Answer: timestamp based locking protocols are used to ensure that only one transaction can access a data item at any given time this is done by assigning each transaction a unique timestamp which is used to determine the order in which transactions are allowed to access the data item the timestamp assigned is usually based on the order in which transactions arrive at the system when a transaction attempts to access a data item it must first check if any other transaction has already locked it by checking its timestamp if another transaction has locked the item with an earlier timestamp then the current transaction must wait until that lock is released before it can proceed once all locks have been released then the current transaction can acquire its own lock and proceed with its operations
User Answer: timestamp based locking protocols are a type of concurrency control protocol used in database management systems to ensure that multiple transactions do not interfere with each other this type of protocol assigns a unique timestamp to each transaction and ensures that no two transactions can access the same data at the same time transactions acquire locks on data items they wish to modify and must wait until all other transactions with earlier timestamps have completed their operations before they can proceed this ensures that all changes made by one transaction are visible to subsequent transactions thus preventing lost updates and other anomalies

Question: Discuss two phase locking protocol and strict two phase locking protocols?
Model Answer: two phase locking protocol the two-phase locking protocol is a concurrency control mechanism that ensures the atomicity of transactions it works by requiring that all transactions acquire locks on the data items they need before they can read or write them and then release all locks when the transaction is complete this ensures that no other transaction can access the same data while it is being used by another transaction thus preventing conflicts between concurrent transactions strict two phase locking protocol the strict two-phase locking protocol is an extension of the two-phase locking protocol in which all locks must be acquired before any data item can be accessed and released only after all operations on it are completed this ensures that a transaction cannot access any data until it has acquired a lock on it thus preventing deadlocks from occurring additionally this also prevents any other transactions from accessing the same data while one transaction is using it ensuring serializability and atomicity of concurrent transactions
User Answer: the two-phase locking protocol divides the execution phase of the transaction into three parts in the first part when the execution of the transaction starts it seeks permission for the lock it requires in the second part the transaction acquires all the locks the third phase is started as soon as the transaction releases its first lock in the third phase the transaction cannot demand any new locks it only releases the acquired locks there are two phases of 2pl growing phase in the growing phase a new lock on the data item may be acquired by the transaction but none can be released shrinking phase in the shrinking phase existing lock held by the transaction may be released but no new locks can be acquired the first phase of strict-2pl is similar to 2pl in the first phase after acquiring all the locks the transaction continues to execute normally the only difference between 2pl and strict 2pl is that strict-2pl does not release a lock after using it strict-2pl waits until the whole transaction to commit and then it releases all the locks at a time strict-2pl protocol does not have shrinking phase of lock release it does not have cascading abort as 2pl does

Question: Discuss Serializability in detail?
Model Answer: serializability is a property of database transactions that ensures that concurrent execution of transactions produces the same result as if the operations were executed serially in some order in other words it means that no matter what order the operations are performed in the end result will be the same serializability is important for maintaining data consistency and preventing lost updates or incorrect results due to race conditions serializability can be achieved by using locks or timestamps to ensure that conflicting operations are not executed concurrently locks are used to prevent two transactions from accessing and modifying the same data item at the same time while timestamps are used to order conflicting operations so they can be safely reordered without affecting correctness in addition to providing serializability locks and timestamps also help ensure transaction isolation by preventing dirty reads reading uncommitted data and non-repeatable reads reading data twice and getting different results serializability also helps prevent phantom reads reading new rows inserted by another transaction
User Answer: serializability is a property of a database transaction that ensures all transactions are executed in the same order as they were submitted it ensures that transactions are isolated from each other so that one transaction does not interfere with another serializable transactions guarantee data integrity and consistency by ensuring that no two transactions will conflict with each other even if they are running concurrently in order to achieve serializability the database system must ensure that all changes made by one transaction are visible to other transactions only after the first transaction has been committed this means that any changes made by one transaction must be completed before any changes made by another transaction can be seen this prevents any conflicts between concurrent transactions and guarantees data integrity and consistency serializability is an important concept in database systems and is used to ensure data integrity and consistency when multiple users access the same data simultaneously it also helps prevent deadlocks which occur when two or more processes try to access the same resource at the same time but cannot do so because of conflicting locks on the resource

Question: Discuss about Complex integrity constraints in SQL?

Question: Define trigger and explain its three parts? Differentiate row level and statement level triggers?
